lens.book_chapters: Part 1: The Cold Start Problem and Atomic Networks.
lens.lens_summary: Roomi performs best where it can form dense hyperlocal roommate micro-markets, but value drops when trust, timing, and commitment mechanics fail to reach a local tipping point.

competitor_overview.primary_strength: Fast, mobile-first matching between people seeking rooms and people listing rooms in major cities
competitor_overview.business_model: Freemium marketplace with paid boosts/premium visibility and messaging-related monetization, which biases UX toward liquidity and response speed
competitor_overview.user_base: Students, young professionals, and relocators who need roommates or rooms quickly in urban markets
competitor_overview.brand_perception: Convenient and active in large metros, but mixed trust perception due to scams/ghosting and variable listing quality

discovery.what_they_do: Roomi is discovered through app stores, social search, and word-of-mouth in high-churn city rental markets; value proposition emphasizes finding a room or roommate quickly.
discovery.framework_analysis: This is Roomi's atomic-network entry point: discovery works when enough users in one city/price band are active simultaneously, helping local clusters cross the cold-start threshold.
discovery.what_nobody_in_category_does: Almost no roommate platforms create neighborhood-by-neighborhood launch playbooks with visible local liquidity signals before signup.

evidence.observation: Networks fail below a minimum density and accelerate after crossing a tipping point.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Discovery messaging should prove local density, not just global user counts; without local density proof, acquisition churn stays high.

evidence.observation: Brand promise is speed and availability in major cities rather than deep trust differentiation at first touch.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Roomi optimizes for entering many local atomic networks where immediacy can create first-session utility.

search.what_they_do: Users filter by city, budget, move-in timing, and room/profile attributes, then browse cards/lists of rooms or potential roommates.
search.framework_analysis: Search benefits directly from network size and side-balance: more active listers and seekers increase match probability and produce a stronger perceived network effect.
search.what_nobody_in_category_does: The category rarely shows real-time market depth by submarket (for example, expected response rates by neighborhood plus move-in window).

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Part I: network value rises with relevant participants)
evidence.observation: A network's practical value increases when the right people are present and interaction is possible.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Search quality depends less on raw listing count and more on relevance density inside each local atomic network.

evidence.observation: Core search is broad and fast but still exposes uneven quality and stale listings in thinner submarkets.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Cold-start pockets persist within cities, indicating some atomic networks never fully tip.

listing_evaluation.what_they_do: Users review photos, bio details, preferences, and profile/listing metadata to judge fit before contacting.
listing_evaluation.framework_analysis: Roomi reaches liquidity faster than trust depth; this creates anti-network pressure where more supply can also mean more uncertainty, forcing users to do extra screening work.
listing_evaluation.what_nobody_in_category_does: Few players make trust density visible (for example, confidence scores combining verification depth, response consistency, and historical reliability).

evidence.observation: As networks scale, relevance and quality can degrade without filtering and anti-spam mechanisms.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Listing evaluation becomes cognitively heavy when ranking and trust signals do not scale with network growth.

evidence.observation: Users frequently report inconsistent listing quality and concern about scams or ghosting.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Weak trust primitives reduce effective network value even when nominal liquidity is high.

booking_proposal.what_they_do: Roomi generally supports connection and intent signaling, but final negotiation/commitment often moves off-platform or remains lightly structured compared with full transaction marketplaces.
booking_proposal.framework_analysis: This is where Roomi's atomic network often breaks: it can generate matches but does not always convert them into high-confidence, on-platform commitments that reinforce defensibility.
booking_proposal.what_nobody_in_category_does: The category largely avoids standardized roommate-offer workflows with explicit terms, milestone confirmation, and mutual pre-commitment checks.

evidence.observation: A strong networked product needs both user connections and robust product mechanics around those connections.
evidence.framework_interpretation: If commitment mechanics are weak, network interactions leak off-platform and feedback loops weaken.

evidence.observation: Conversation is supported, but formalized offer-to-agreement flow is not the category's strongest layer.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Conversion from match to signed living arrangement is a fragile point in the network lifecycle.

communication.what_they_do: In-app messaging enables introductions, screening, and logistics; response speed is a major success driver.
communication.framework_analysis: Messaging is Roomi's magic-moment engine: once both sides exchange timely, relevant messages, local network value becomes immediately tangible and retention improves.
communication.what_nobody_in_category_does: Few roommate products orchestrate structured conversation prompts that reduce ghosting and accelerate trust formation in the first 48 hours.

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Part I: engagement increases when network interactions are active)
evidence.observation: Users stay when other users are active and interactions are meaningful.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Fast bilateral messaging is the behavioral trigger that confirms network utility.

evidence.observation: Response latency strongly predicts conversion in two-sided matching products.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Communication quality can compensate for moderate search imperfections and push an atomic network past tipping.

active_stay.what_they_do: Roomi has limited or no core workflow for co-living operations once people move in; ongoing stay management is mostly off-platform.
active_stay.framework_analysis: The network loop ends too early: Roomi captures pre-match interactions but not the high-value in-stay behavior that could deepen trust data and future matching quality.
active_stay.what_nobody_in_category_does: Most roommate platforms do not turn active co-living into a productized network layer with shared routines, issue resolution, and behavior signals.

evidence.observation: Primary product surface is discovery/matching rather than post-move relationship management.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Without post-match participation, the network cannot compound through richer interaction data.

post_stay.what_they_do: Post-tenancy feedback and portable reputation are limited compared with what is needed for strong repeat trust loops.
post_stay.framework_analysis: Missing post-stay reputation loops weaken network defensibility because each new search feels partially reset instead of benefiting from accumulated trust capital.
post_stay.what_nobody_in_category_does: The category rarely builds durable, standardized roommate reputation graphs that transfer across cities and life stages.

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Part I: maintaining network quality requires mechanisms beyond raw growth)
evidence.observation: Unchecked growth can degrade usefulness unless quality controls and relevance systems improve carrying capacity.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Post-stay reputation is a quality-control mechanism that increases carrying capacity for trust-sensitive marketplaces.

retention.what_they_do: Retention is episodic and event-driven; users return during life transitions (new city, lease turnover, roommate change) rather than as a daily habit.
retention.framework_analysis: Roomi's retention follows network-cycle bursts: strong during urgent housing windows, weak between events, making each return vulnerable to mini cold starts in narrower segments.
retention.what_nobody_in_category_does: The category underinvests in long-term identity and relationship layers that keep users warm between housing events.

evidence.observation: Roommate search products show cyclical usage tied to lease and relocation timing.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Without persistent value between moves, network effects are periodic instead of continuously compounding.

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Part I: collapse risk when networks dip below activity thresholds)
evidence.observation: Networks can unwind when active participation falls below critical density.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Retention strategy must preserve minimum local activity to avoid repeated cold-start dynamics.

split_lease_phase_mapping.discovery: Split Lease Phase 1 (Host Creates a Listing) and Phase 2 (Guest Creates a Proposal)
split_lease_phase_mapping.search: Split Lease Phase 2 (Guest Creates a Proposal)
split_lease_phase_mapping.listing_evaluation: Split Lease Phase 2 (Guest reviews listing details before proposal)
split_lease_phase_mapping.booking_proposal: Split Lease Phase 2 (Submit Proposal), Phase 3 (Host Counter), and Phase 4 (Guest Accepts Terms)
split_lease_phase_mapping.communication: Split Lease Phase 3-5 (Negotiation notifications and active lease messaging)
split_lease_phase_mapping.active_stay: Split Lease Phase 5 (Leases, Stay Management, Date Change Tool, House Manual)
split_lease_phase_mapping.post_stay: Split Lease Phase 5 (Stay Review and post-stay feedback loop)
split_lease_phase_mapping.retention: Split Lease cross-phase re-engagement via Listings, Proposals, Leases, and repeat stays

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: Trust infrastructure is shallow at the exact moment users need to commit to living together
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Hard to standardize across jurisdictions and expensive to moderate, while monetization is easier from lead generation than commitment assurance
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Cold Start and atomic-network logic imply that weak trust at commitment prevents local networks from tipping into durable repeat loops

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: Post-match and post-stay behavior data is not captured as a reusable reputation asset
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Most products define success as match creation, not co-living outcomes, so they stop investing after chat handoff
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Without downstream interaction data, the network cannot increase carrying capacity or defend against anti-network effects like scams and ghosting

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: Local liquidity is marketed as global scale instead of precise neighborhood-time-window density
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Global growth narratives are simpler for acquisition and fundraising than exposing thin pockets transparently
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Atomic networks win only when users can see enough relevant participants in their exact context; otherwise the perceived network effect is overstated
